[h1]Data Types[/h1]

The term [b]data type[/b] refers to the types of values with which a program can work. JavaScript variables can hold many data types, such as [b]numbers[/b], [b]strings[/b], [b]arrays[/b], and more.

Unlike many other programming languages, JavaScript does not define different types of numbers, like integers, short, long, floating-point, etc.

JavaScript numbers can be written with or without decimals.[code format="js"]var num = 42; // A number without decimals[/code]

answers.text: Is allowed to have a decimal place

quizzes.question: A floating point number:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Floating-Point Numbers[/h1]

JavaScript numbers can also have decimals.[code format="js" codeId="649"]<script>
  var price = 55.55;
  document.write(price);
</script>[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2742" width="100%"]
[note]JavaScript numbers are always stored as [b]double precision floating point numbers[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: In order to create a string, we need to put the text inside...
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Strings[/h1]

JavaScript [b]strings [/b]are used for storing and manipulating text.
A string can be any text that appears within [b]quotes[/b]. You can use single or double quotes.[code format="js"]var name = 'John';
var text = "My name is John Smith";[/code]
You can use quotes inside a string, as long as they don't match the quotes surrounding the string.[code format="js"]var text = "My name is 'John' ";[/code]

[h1]Strings[/h1]

As strings must be written within quotes, quotes inside the string must be handled. The [b]backslash (\) escape characte[/b]r turns special characters into string characters. [code format="js" codeId="650"]var sayHello = 'Hello world! [b]\'[/b]I am a JavaScript programmer.[b]\'[/b] ';
document.write(sayHello);[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [img id="2743" width="100%"]
The escape character (\) can also be used to insert other special characters into a string.
These special characters can be added to a text string using the backslash sign. [img id="2786" width="100%"]
[note]If you begin a string with a single quote, then you should also end it with a single quote. The same rule applies to double quotes. Otherwise, JavaScript will become confused.[/note]

quizzes.question: What two values does the Boolean data type accept?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Booleans[/h1]

In JavaScript Boolean, you can have one of two values, either [b]true [/b]or [b]false[/b]. 
These are useful when you need a data type that can only have one of two values, such as Yes/No, On/Off, True/False.

[b]Example: [/b] [code format="js"]var isActive = true; 
var isHoliday = false;[/code]
[note]The Boolean value of 0 (zero), null, undefined, empty string is [b]false[/b].
Everything with a "real" value is [b]true[/b].[/note]
